Amazon Glacier is designed for?
note: Glacier is an archival storage service. You're charged every-time you access data over the free tier threshold. When you put data in Glacier you want to have a reasonable expectation that you'll at most need to recover a small portion at most per-month unless there is a disaster/emergency scenario.

question1: Your web application front end consists of multiple EC2 instances behind an Elastic Load Balancer. You configured ELB to perform health checks on these EC2 instances. If an instance fails to pass health checks, which statement will be true?

list.A: The instance is replaced automatically by the ELB
list.B: The instance gets terminated automatically by the ELB
list.C: The ELB stops sending traffic to the instance that failed its health check
list.D: The instance gets quarantined by the ELB for root cause analysis

note: ELBs are deigned to dynamically forward traffic to the eth0 interface of some set of ec2 instances in one or more availability zones of a single region. When monitoring is setup the ELB will see that the instance isn't responding and stop sending traffic to the failed instance.

question1: You are building a system to distribute confidential training videos to employees. Using CloudFront, what method could be used to serve content that is stored in S3, but not publically accessible from S3 directly?

list.A: Create an Origin Access Identity (OAI) for CloudFront and grant access to the objects in your S3 bucket to that OAI.
list.B: Add the CloudFront account security group “amazon-cf/amazon-cf-sg” to the appropriate S3 bucket policy.
list.C: Create an Identity and Access Management (IAM) User for CloudFront and grant access to the objects in your S3 bucket to that IAM User.
list.D: Create a S3 bucket policy that lists the CloudFront distribution ID as the Principal and the target bucket as the Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

note: CloudFront is a CDN capability that distributes S3 objects geographically. An OAI is sort of like a service account for a CloudFront distribution. Using an OAI you can restrict access to S3 content effectively preventing direct access to content in S3 but still allowing CloudFront access to distribute that data.

question1: Which of the following will occur when an EC2 instance in a VPC (Virtual Private Cloud) with an associated Elastic IP is stopped and started?

list.A: The Elastic IP will be dissociated from the instance
list.B: All data on instance-store devices will be lost
list.C: All data on EBS (Elastic Block Store) devices will be lost
list.D: The ENI (Elastic Network Interface) is detached

note: It's important in this question to note that the instance is in a VPC to rule out other answers. Any instance storage device is only persisted during the running life of the instance because instance storage is physically attached to the host rather than NAS storage like EBS. Now part of the reason that instance storage only persists while an instance is powered on is because the host could/always changes when the instance is started. Remember that instance resources are very loosely coupled with other resources. When you start an instance it gets a resource reservation on a carefully chosen, presumably with some complex algorithm, available host.

question1: In the basic monitoring package for EC2, Amazon CloudWatch provides the following metrics:

list.A: web server visible metrics such as number failed transaction requests
list.B: operating system visible metrics such as memory utilization
list.C: database visible metrics such as number of connections
list.D: hypervisor visible metrics such as CPU utilization

note: A responsibility boundary exists between the hypervisor and guest operating system. AWS does not have access to the guest operating system and therefore cannot see anything that isn't visible to the hypervisor. Such information would be resource demands of the guest operating system that the hypervisor must service like, CPU usage. Refer back to the shared responsibility model discussed in the AWS Security Whitepaper. http://d36cz9buwru1tt.cloudfront.net/pdf/AWS_Security_Whitepaper.pdf

question1: Which is an operational process performed by AWS for data security?

list.A: AES-256 encryption of data stored on any shared storage device
list.B: Decommissioning of storage devices using industry-standard practices
list.C: Replication of data across multiple AWS Regions
list.D: Secure wiping of EBS data when an EBS volume is unmounted

note: The key to this question is understanding again the shared responsibility boundary between AWS and its customers as well as the specific statement "operational process". Again we need to refer to the AWS Security Whitepaper. As a standard practice AWS shreds all physical disks after magnetically wiping them as part of their decommissioning process.

question1: To protect S3 data from both accidental deletion and accidental overwriting, you should:

list.A: enable S3 versioning on the bucket
list.B: access S3 data using only signed URLs
list.C: disable S3 delete using an IAM bucket policy

note: By enabling versioning you ensure that if accidentally or otherwise overwritten any previous object version is persisted as a previous version. In addition you protect against complete loss from accidental deletion
